Her martied in IB95 and for many years made a living for his family by
teaching school and farming, until finally hie determination to be a poet caused
him to go to England where he remained for three years in what he felt was a
more creative environment. His first work, "A Boy’s Will" (1913) was published
there when he was thirty-nine years old.
He returned to America and continued to write about the people who lived
and worked on the farm. He took for his subject the relationship of man to his
surroundings ("Two Look at Two", "Stopping By Woods on a Snowy Evening”, and
"Birches"). The theme of loneliness is evident in "The Runaway", "The Sound of
Trees" and "Desert Places"*
Frost received the Bilitzer Prize in 1924, 1931, 1$37, and 19^3. In i960,
the late President John F. Kennedy asked the poet to compose and read a poem
for the presidential inauguration ceremony, which he did.
Robert Frost was greatly cherished by his readers, and is regarded by many
as America’s finest poet*
IV. VOCABULARY NOTES
fetch, shan’t?
These words are rather unusual in modem American English. They can still
be heard in certain geographical areas of the United States, chiefly in th«
rural, northeastern areas of the country. This use of colloquial terms
adds a special flavor of actual rural speech to this poem about the
pleasure of doing simple farm chores.
clear?
This word is also used in an abstract sensei "The situation will clear
if we think rationally about the problem." Frequently, clear up is used
as a two-word verb with the same meaning as clear* Up in this position
means "completely" ("% headache cleared up after I rested"). Other
examples of this use of up ares He raked up the leaves# The calf drank
up the milk. She cleaned up the room before she left#
